Target Usage:
• Provide energy generation schedules with historical, actual and forecasted data
  • Provide services for the Complex Event Processing engine
  • Data handler between different components
Name: Generation Schedule Manager DSE

Documentation.Description:
The Generation Schedule Manager retrieves energy generation data in a documented format from the different possible sources, in this case the wind, solar and biogas DERs.

As shown in the figure the data will be collected in storage and the needed data for e.g. a given time period will be retrieved and processed.

The Generation Schedule Manager provides the information about energy generation. It determines the actual generation of the energy resources and delivers the forecasted data as well as the historical data. The information can be accessed via services as described below.

On the energy generation side the data from all renewable energy sources for the generated energy is gathered. Likewise the energy consumption of the smart factory is gathered. Also there are forecasted data for the DERs as well as for the smart factory. The data itself is structured in equidistant time intervals.

This overview already shows that there is the same overall structure of the energy generation and energy consumption side and this is reflected in the resulting structure of all the data.

Combining the DSEs Generation Schedule Manager and Production Schedule Manager

Depending on the use case and the access rights the data structure for the energy generation and the energy consumption can be separated or combined to provide easier access. This leads to a homogenous approach for the API allowing the access to the DSE. The combination can be achieved by joining the data structure under the same base directory, thus enabling the a joined data access also considered in the implementation of the API. The relevant requests are able to handle the combined data structure.

In the definition of the API, Data Access, below the combined access to the energy generation and energy consumption data is indicated by the section of the request responses marked by the key word “consumption”.

Data Structure

In the following the resulting structure, which allows for addressing and providing specific data, is described.

The energy generation is composed of components, which generate energy. The data for each component is provided by values for equidistant time intervals. This leads to the following overall structure for the data of the components.

Generation

Generation-component_1
Generation-component_2
….
Generation-component_N

Each component has data for measured values and for calculated values. Calculated values may be for example for forecasted energy generation. Furthermore the data is grouped by day, so that the values for a component of measured or calculated data for one day is combined.

Component_A

measurement

day_1
day_2
….
day_n

calculation

day_1
day_2
….
day_m

The data for a component is structured in values, which are provided for an equidistant time interval. The data for one point of time consists of several values and is represented by one line of values that are separated by comma. The end of the line is marked by a semicolon.

The line consists of the values, which are measured or calculated for the energy like e.g. an amount and a factor for further calculations and processing, both depending on the electric metering interfaces of the component.

The first line of data is the headline describing the contents of each column, so that with the information of the headline the value of the respective column can be interpreted and accordingly further processed. The headline is followed by the lines of the values for each point of time, a line giving the data for one point of time and the lines representing the point of time given in consecutive order of time. The number of lines of values for one day depends on the equidistant time interval, which defines the amount of time between the values of consecutive lines.

There is data for each day for which data is provided for a component. The data has the format:

Headline: <Description column_1>,…….,<Description column_n>;
Data Line_1: <value_1>,…………………………..,<value_n>;
…..
Data Line_N: <value_1>,…………………………..,<value_n>;

The resulting structure, as shown below, allows for accessing and providing specific data for a specific component and a specific day in a uniform way for all components.

Generation

Generation-component_1

measurement

day_1
….
day_n

calculation

day_1
….
day_m

….
Generation-component_N

….

By specifying each element in the hierarchy the data is uniquely described and can be accessed.

Data Access

According to the structure of the data described above the data of the components is structured by day and thus can be accessed per day. Data access is allowed for reading or writing. The overall structure of the data of all components is designed in a way that it can be accessed in a uniform way.

In this implementation the access to the data is handled on a user basis. In the initial registration to the system a user gets an authentication-id and password with which he authenticates himself to the system for a request or a series of requests.

In the authentication process to initiate requests the user gets an authorisation-id for the requests. This id is then given as a parameter to the requests. The authorisation and authentication of users is not part of the DSE. Therefore a basic implementation of the access rights is used.

For each user there is a list of components to which he is granted access, more specifically, which he is allowed to read or write. The list comprises a subset of the list of components for energy generation and consumption. Out of this list of components the user can request data for a component for a specific day, which are measured or calculated.

To access the data the component, measurement or calculation, the date and the id for user authorisation must be specified. This way the data as described in the structure above is uniquely specified and can be accessed. The process for a user to access data for energy generation includes the following steps.
  • User authentication
  • Getting the list of components for which access is allowed for the user including the information whether it may be read or written.
  • Getting the list of available data for a component
  • Accessing the specified data

First the user authenticates himself to the system using his authentication-id and password. An authorisation-id is sent back for subsequent requests of the user. Each request must be authorised by giving the authorisation-id as a parameter. Next, using the authorisation-id the user requests the list of components he is granted access to. The list contains a unique identification for the component and the information whether the data may be read or written. The unique identification for the component is used in further requests to get information for this component.

In the next step the available data for a component is requested. The returned list contains the dates for which data is available each for measurement and calculation. This means for each element of the list data exists for the given day. The list gives a unique reference to this data with which it can be accessed in subsequent requests.

Following these steps the user can request to access the required data of the components. In the requests to access the data the reference to the data is given and the data for the specified date is returned.There are requests for reading and writing the data. The requests are constructed in a uniform way to allow for a consistent use.

The access to the system is implemented in a RESTful API. The application is compliant with the REST conventions. It performs the requested service as a response to GET or POST requests as stated in the description of the interface to the specific URLs. The input data and the responses of this service are by default provided in JSON format.

User authentication

This service authenticates a user to the system.

authenticateUser

function name authenticateUser
description Authenticates a user to the system
function prototype String authenticateUser ()
parameter authentication-id, password
return type String
return description Unique authorisation-id
REST Status Codes 200: OK
404: Not Found
500: Internal Server Error
503: Service Unavailable

URL
https:///authentication?Authentication-ID=<authentication-id>
&UserPassword=<password>

HTTP request method: POST

Response
{
"authorisation-id": "<authorisation-id">
}

Get user list of components

This service delivers the list of components for a user to which he is granted access.

getUserComponentList

function name getUserComponentList
description gets the list of allowed components for a user
function prototype String getUserComponentList ()
parameter User authorisation-id
return type String
return description List of components
REST Status Codes 200: OK
404: Not Found
500: Internal Server Error (:= data is not accessible)
503: Service Unavailable

URL
https:///UserComponentLists?authorisation-id=<authorisation-id>

HTTP request method: GET

Response

{
"generation": [
{
"component": "<component-id>",
"url": "<apibaseurl>/generation/<component-id>",
"access": "<access-right>"
},
……..
],
"consumption": [
{
} ,
……..
]
}

There are the following access rights to the data of a component

Access right Abbreviation
read r
write w
read, write rw

Documentation.Preface:
Within this document you find a self-contained open specification of the aforementioned Domain Specific Enabler (DSE).

Please consult the appropriate pages on the FINESCE website in order to understand the complete context of the related FINESCE trials and this DSE.

Terms and Conditions: This DSE will be available as Open Source (Apache License 2.0).
Contact Person:
Adelheid Weinert
QSC AG
Adelheid.weinertREMOVE-NO-SPAM@qsc.de
Overview:
In work package 3 of the Finesce Project a virtual supply unit is set up. Renewable energy sources (DERs) such as wind power, solar power and biomass are virtually interconnected and used as one supply unit, as a Virtual Power Plant. A Demand-Side-Management is developed in a partnership with a smart factory as a sample consumer. This management system is used to find the optimal balance between energy generation and demand.

To be able to develop the applications and services for the management system, the data for the energy generation side is needed. The balancing between the energy generation of the VPP and the consumption by the Smart Factory is done based on the forecasted energy generation of the VPP for the day-ahead and a variation of energy profiles for the production of the factory.

Other applications like the monitoring are based on the measured data for the energy generation. For the energy generation the historical data and the actual and forecasted data are provided.
Downloads: Downloads for this DSE are not available yet.
Instances: An instance of this DSE’s reference implementation runs as a part of the trial and is not publicly accessible.
